Problem:
Consider a fluid mechanic system where the velocity field \\( \\vec{v}(x, t) \\) is governed by the Navier-Stokes equation \\( \\partial_t \\vec{v} + (\\vec{v} \\cdot \\nabla)\\vec{v} = -\\frac{1}{\\rho} \\nabla p + \\nu \\nabla^2 \\vec{v} \\). We introduce a scalar field temperature \\( T(x,t) \\) affected by both convection and diffusion, described by the advection-diffusion equation \\( \\partial_t T + \\vec{v} \\cdot \\nabla T = \\kappa \\nabla^2 T \\), where \\( \\kappa \\) is the diffusion coefficient.

If an intervention alters the diffusion coefficient \\( \\kappa \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) in a controlled manner, does the resultant temperature distribution \\( T(x, T) \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) solely depend on the new diffusion coefficient and not on the previous velocity field changes?
Explanation: Even with the change in \\( \\kappa \\), the temperature distribution at time T depends on both the altered diffusion dynamics and the prior state and evolution of the velocity field. The changes in \\( \\vec{v}(x, t) \\) prior to \\( t_1 \\) influence the initial conditions and trajectory of temperature distribution."
